node.text:
Take Pokemon-like gameplay, throw in NFTs and you have Axie Infinity.

The game lets players like 22-year-old John Aaron Ramos accumulate tradeable crypto coins and earn real money — in his case, enough to buy two apartments. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Axie Infinity: How a Game is Turning Players Into Crypto Traders

node.text: NFTs burst on the scene with a $69 million sale of Beeple's digital art. Now players behind the so-called metaverse are betting "digital scarcity" will create a whole new ecosystem of play and commerce.

node.title: How NFTs Are Reinventing the Digital World

node.text:
"I would describe cryptocurrencies as a limited supply of nothing."

John Paulson—who's famous bet against subprime housing made him and investors $20 billion—says crypto is a "worthless" bubble and he calls SPACs, one of the hottest investing tools, a losing proposition.

Paulson told @bloombergtv in an interview on "Bloomberg Wealth with David Rubenstein" he's more concerned about rising prices. The rapidly expanding money supply could push inflation rates well above current expectations, he said, and gold, which he’s backed for years, is primed for its moment.

Paulson’s dismissal of crypto is sure to attract critics after digital assets vastly outperformed gold in recent years. Watch the full episode Tuesday at 9pm ET on BloombergTV and read the Big Take in our stories.

node.title: Cryptocurrencies are a Bubble, Says Billionaire Paulson

node.text: Frackers in America’s largest oil field are letting massive amounts of methane spill into the atmosphere. These scientists and activists are trying to find the leaks and get them plugged before they cook the planet further.

node.title: The Methane Hunters Racing to Change the Course of Global Warming

node.title: What Happens When You Mix Covid Vaccines?

node.text: Few people have lost as much money as quickly as Bill Hwang. In March, the previously unknown Wall Street whale and his family firm, Archegos, triggered losses of more than $20 billion in just two days. The result was one of the most spectacular implosions in modern financial history. (via @businessweek)

node.title: How Archegos Capital Cost Wall Street $20 Billion

node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

node.text:
In almost every way measurable, millennials in the U.S. at 40 are doing worse financially than the generations that came before them.

Fewer millennials own homes than their parents did at their age. They have more debt — especially student debt. They simply aren’t as wealthy. 

Now, if predictions of a long, post-Covid economic boom are to be believed, this may be the last opportunity an entire generation has to build wealth before heading off into retirement.

node.title: Millennials Are Running Out of Time to Build Wealth to Retire

node.text: When employees at software company 10Pines want a raise, they pitch their co-workers, not their boss. Here's what happens when a firm uses "radical transparency" to attract and retain talent.

node.title: Would You Let Your Colleagues Decide Your Salary?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 06, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Millions of Americans are stucki backlog nightmare asjobless benefits expire Bloomberg'.

node.text:
For millions of Americans, the Labor Day weekend will bring the end of federally funded emergency unemployment benefits and a lurch into the uncertain economic recovery.

Then there are those stranded in a bureaucratic nightmare, still waiting for benefits they are owed.

State agencies that handle these payments have long suffered from antiquated systems and a chronic lack of staffing. The pandemic made it worse with the massive influx of people who lost their jobs and a wave of alleged fraud that led states to freeze numerous claims. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Over time, subtle differences between the Pfizer and Moderna Covid vaccines have emerged across patient groups. 

Much of the focus has been on levels of antibodies, which serve as one of the immune system’s front-line defenses. One theory about Moderna’s vaccine is that it creates more of those antibodies because it uses a larger dose and the two doses are administered over a one-week longer period than Pfizer’s. 

But antibodies are just one component of immunity and it isn’t clear if they are the most important one, especially over the long-term. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 05, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Mukesh Ambani takes leap toward joining the exclusive $100 billion club Bloom Wealth'.

node.text:
Asia's richest man is knocking on the door of one of the world’s most exclusive clubs: those with fortunes of $100 billion or above.
 
The latest leap in Mukesh Ambani's net worth came after he doubled down on his green-energy plans, saying Reliance Industries would "aggressively" pursue production of cheaper green hydrogen. That sent shares of his flagship firm surging to a record, boosting his fortune to $92.6 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

Ten people are already in the $100 billion club; if he makes it, Ambani would be the only member from Asia. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.text:
Take Pokemon-like gameplay, throw in NFTs and you have Axie Infinity.

The game lets players like 22-year-old John Aaron Ramos accumulate tradeable crypto coins and earn real money — in his case, enough to buy two apartments. (via @quicktake)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Bloomberg Business on September 05, 2021 tagging @bloombergopinion. May be an image of screen, phone and text that says 'Online pornhas shaped the internet as we know it NISTH BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The sex industry has long been an engine for tech progress and, as @bloombergopinion’s Leonid Bershidsky writes, the OnlyFans debate proves it still is.

Back when life on the internet was concentrated in Usenet groups, five out of six images shared were estimated to be pornographic. In 2006, adult content accounted for more than 20% of Google searches from mobile phones. But the early internet and early phones weren’t really suited to high-quality porn.

Because there was a perpetual demand for more, different and better pornographic products, bandwidth needed to grow and did so. Without it, online payment solutions wouldn’t have developed as quickly as they did: There wasn’t all that much people wanted to pay for on the web besides erotic content.

Porn may no longer have the power to shape mass-market demand for new tech, but it can serve as a litmus test for new privacy-oriented solutions. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.text:
Electric vehicle tech has finally arrived in agriculture.

Battery breakthroughs are helping a small crop of startups attract investors hungry for the next new thing on wheels. One of the leaders in the field is Monarch Tractor, co-founded by Mark Schwager — the man best known for designing and building Tesla's Nevada Gigafactory.
 
This is the result: battery-powered, self-driving machines that guide themselves around fields and vineyards in the small hours making about as much noise as a toaster. See more at the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 05, 2021. May be an image of dessert and text that says 'Singaporew wins most Michelin stars ever despite dining restrictions Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Singapore now has a third three-star Michelin restaurant, along with five two-stars and 41 one-star establishments, the most accumulated stars it’s been awarded since the guide started ranking there in 2016.

The achievement comes despite restaurant dining in Singapore whipsawing between open and shut, with many establishments forced to create takeaway or delivery services to survive the pandemic.

Among those with a seat at the top table is Zen, a Nordic restaurant with a fixed menu that’s S$480 ($356) per guest before drinks. It joins Les Amis and Odette with three stars. See the full list at the link in bio.

node.text: NFTs burst on the scene with a $69 million sale of Beeple's digital art. Now players behind the so-called metaverse are betting "digital scarcity" will create a whole new ecosystem of play and commerce.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 04, 2021. May be an image of food and text that says 'A star chef shares his secret for "re-aging" steak Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Employed by butchers and steakhouses for decades, dry aging has become non-negotiable on menus in the past decade or so. The result, for those that aren’t already indoctrinated, is a more intense, meaty flavor with a better crust as moisture comes out of the steak over time.

It’s not hard to do, and home aging machines are increasingly available. But there’s an easier way to improve the dry aged cuts you buy at the market. Chef Andrew Carmellini of Carne Mare suggests “re-aging” your prime steaks in your refrigerator — a process he says is “especially good for a steak for two”. Find out more in the link in bio.

📷: Carne Mare

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Tim Cook has been Apple's CEO for decade. Who will replace him? Bloomberg'.
Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 04, 2021. May be an image of airplane, outdoors and text.

node.text:
Corporate travel as we've known it is a thing of the past.

A Bloomberg survey of 45 large companies in the U.S., Europe and Asia found 84% plan to slash travel budgets post-pandemic. The majority are aiming for cuts of between 20% and 40%.

The future isn't just Zoom calls. Businesses are investing in augmented reality and slashing stipends as they seek out ways to reduce their spending on trips. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '"Cryptocurrencies area bubble. Iwould describe them as limited supply of nothing. John Paulson President, Paulson & Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Ever since billionaire investor John Paulson bet against the U.S. home market last decade, people keep asking him about the next big trade.

In an exclusive interview with Bloomberg TV, he shared his thoughts for the hottest investments of this era. “I wouldn’t recommend anyone invest in cryptocurrencies,” Paulson said adding SPACs will also be a losing proposition.

The investor said he thinks cryptocurrencies are a bubble that will “eventually prove to be worthless.” Link in bio to read the full interview.
